title: Moment in time: Nov. 1, 1512: Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling unveiled to the public -- If almost...

attachments.displayName:
Moment in time: Nov. 1, 1512: Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling unveiled to the public -- If almost 50 years after its theatrical release The Agony and the Ecstasy is remembered for anything, it's likely for Charlton Heston's scenes as a plaster-flecked Michelangelo painting up a storm flat on his back, a nose-breadth from the ceiling of the Vatican's Sistine Chapel. Certainly creating the most famous mural in the world was an endurance test, spanning four years. But there's consensus that, contra Hollywood, the artist did his biblical scenes standing up, albeit with much painful back-bending. Where film does dovetail with fact is in its depiction of Michelangelo as reluctant painter. In 1508, he was known first and foremost as a sculptor. Pope Julius II, however, was an insistent patron. Here, he declared, was a great occasion. Rise to it. -- James Adams

Photo: Plinio Lepri/AP
